segments.text: His age might have been a factor.
His health might have been a factor.
These leaders in the communist bloc tend to be elderly men who have survived in very rough political failures, and they tend to be not robust in their health.
He also, Hillbrook, was also a very hardline communist, a very unpresentable in a way, someone that people in the West didn't like.
And it may have been just decided that as a response of the time that it was a good
somebody else come on, but I don't remember that it was a dispute over an issue or anything like that.
Do you think the Russians used Berlin as an incentive for the U.S. to get involved in SALT?
No, I don't think so.
I think Berlin, as an issue, stood on its own merits, had to do with their long-term stabilization of
of Eastern Europe and so forth.
To some extent, you might say, these things are all interrelated, but I just don't
I'm not sure it would have anything directly involved as impact.
I think it would indicate at the highest strategic level to the Soviets that events were unfolding
And that any sign of a ruckus or coming together of the Chinese and the Americans and so forth was not a good thing for the Soviets.
So they would have not liked it and so forth.
But what they were doing in Europe, particularly with reference to Berlin, was moving in the right direction anyway.
made a big cooptie-doo out of this.
They thought this was something great.
Whether it was wise or not, it's hard to say.
Because you see, you have a lot of Soviet presence anyway, as far as security is concerned.
You have to assume that they've got millions, not millions, but lots of spies there, a lot of agents there.
They come in there.
So it appeared to be necessary or something that was going to make the agreement possible.
And it could have been a lot worse than that, I think.
We could have probably given up a lot more than that.
I don't know what they've gotten out of it.
I don't know what they get out of that.
What are the secret protocols?

that we would try to restrict the travel of these bad people, sort of like the Ku Klux Klan, but politically, you know, neo-Nazis.
I can't remember that, but again, it would have been quite a
I think that it was whether all the governments agreed that they were prepared to act to implement the concept that they taught in a real way, in a practical way.
We all had problems.
Assuringly, we had problems with Berlin.
issue arose was valuable to us.
Also, as I said, we had been pursuing the other policy that Germany was only one Germany, Germany was undivided, etc., that East Germany was not a real government, and so forth.
And we really hadn't gotten very far with it.
Both sides were stonewalling.

and come up with an agreement that did in effect

Power was what we really wanted.
But we thought we could, we thought we had the Soviets where they would give us more than one.
We thought we could get more than power.
We thought they wanted them badly enough.
So that's the way we maneuvered.

They eventually got him out.
